subcategory: Inadequate Number of Females Available for Panel Interviews

content.text: This refers to the phenomenon when there are not enough females who are able or willing to participate in panel interviews, which further creates gender bias in the workplace.
Insufficient number of females in the workforce, due to which there are fewer females available for the panel interviews.
Limited number of female managers in the organisation can make it difficult to find relevant females for interview panels.
Unconscious bias can favour appointment of male interviewers, reinforcing gender stereotypes, and positioning men as better evaluators and decision-makers.
Workplace cultures can discourage female participation in panel interviews and leadership roles, reducing their willingness to volunteer.
Try to attract and retain more females in the workforce by promoting a healthy organizational culture.
Continuously and consistently develop females for managerial positions.
Conduct unconscious bias training to reduce favouritism towards male interviewers.
Cultivate an inclusive workplace culture that empowers and encourages female participation in panel interviews and leadership roles.
